summary.abstract: This article surveys five major Arabic geographers from the 9th to 12th centuries—Ibn Rosteh, al-Istakhri, Ibn Haukal, al-Masudi, and al-Idrisi—and their contributions to describing the shape, size, and peoples of the Earth. The Arabic geographical tradition drew on Greek astronomical knowledge, particularly Ptolemy's cartographic framework, while developing distinctive world maps that divided the known world into seven climatic zones. Al-Masudi's historical-geographical synthesis and al-Idrisi's Tabula Rogeriana, created for the Norman king Roger II of Sicily, represent high points of the tradition. The medieval Arabic astronomers preserved Greek knowledge during the European Dark Ages and made original contributions to cartographic method.
